detailsOfAchievement: Have been published thirteen volumes on Indian History in a series of Peoples History of India with thirty six projected volumes besides other numerous research works such as CASTE IN INDIAN HISTORY and RELIGION IN HISTORY HISTORY Held annual research seminars regularly since two thousand one Issued biannual research journal Studies in Peoples History through SAGE four volumes eight issues already published

sourceOfFunds.purpose: Study of Indian Business and Economy in the past/ Seminar held on Merchants Trade in History at which twenty-one papers were read it was attended by scholars faculty and students A book was published titled Indian Economy under Early British Rule seventh eighteenth century fourth edition of which came out in two thousand sixteen

Study of Social in India A seminar was held on Forms of Inequality in Indian History in which twenty four papers per read covering the forms inequalities in India from the Indus Valley Civilization to the nineteenth century detailed discussion were held among scholars in the present of a large gathering of faculty and students A Peoples History of India no seven SOCIETY AND CULTURE IN POST MAURYAN INDIA was published of which second edition came out on 2016

Study of Political and Religious History A Seminar in State and Religion in India was held in which twenty two papers were presented on different themes covering state and religion from pre historic to first half of the twentieth century these were well debated and the seminar was well attended by faculty students and scholars A Peoples History of India no twenty three THE ESTABLISHMENT OF BRITISH RULE SEVENTEEN FIFTY SEVEN TO EIGHTEEN THIRTEEN was published the second ed came out next year

Study of Regional History of India and Medieval Indian Economy Seminar was held on India and Its Part Past and the Present twenty six papers per read stimulating discussion took place in which faculty members and scholars contributed a big gathering remained present A Peoples History of India no Fourteen ECONOMIC HISTORY OF INDIA The Period of the Delhi Sultanate and the Vijayanagara Empire was published paper back edition due to come out shortly

detailsOfAchievement: AICURD has been quite instrumental towards empowerment of marginalized people aiming at their sustainable livelihood. Accordingly AICURD has formed almost 520 SHGs in different blocks of Jalpaiguri district, Wet Bengal. by this time 325 SHGs have been graded and credit linked. For promotion of handicrafts in Jalpaiguri district by making arrangements of supply of raw materials, technological inputs, training to artisans, marketing support etc. AICURD was allowed a project under Baba Sahib Ambedkar Hastha Silpa Vikas Yogana (AHVY) in Nov. 2001 from Development Commissioner (H), Ministry of Textiles, GOI. Accordingly 16 SHGs consisting of 240 artisans availed training etc. for Jute, Cane, Bamboo & weaving activities. In the year 2007-08 similar assistance was granted to AICURD under AHVY. Skill development workshop for 6 months covering 20 artisans, design development workshop for 15 days covering 30 artisans and integrated design & technical development project for 6 months covering 75 nos. of artisans were successfully organized. AICURD has set up a Craft Development Centre (CDC) on diversified jute products at Jalpaiguri with financial assistance from Development Commissioner (H), Ministry of Textiles, GOI. Non availability of credit in time is a major problem of the SHGs for their involvement in income generating activities. With a view to obviate this bottle neck AICURD provided credit support to SHGs. Most of group members are engaged in agriculture, small business, animal husbandry, cottage industry etc. Their repayment is almost 90%. Credit decision is taken by group members in their meeting. AICURD has organized a child labour school at Jalpaiguri aided by NCLP (Labour Dept. Govt. of West Bengal). Children of age group 9 to 14 years engaged in hazardous activities were admitted. We are providing formal education and vocational training to the children. There is arrangement of full meal at noon. We have organized ten crÃ¨che centres for the children of working mothers in Sadar block of Jalpaiguri district, W.B. It is funded by Central Social Welfare Board/ West Bengal Social Welfare Board. Children of age group 0 to 6 years are admitted. There are 2 creche workers in each centre. We offer pre-primary education, health support and nutrition to the children. Most of the mothers of children belong to BPL category, they have formed a few SHGs. Ministry of Food Processing Industries, GOI has sanctioned a project of FPTC in the financial year 2008-09. Members of SHGs are beneficiaries. Grounding of the project is mostly completed. Nehru Yuva Kendra sponsored skill development training programme for women members of SHG on â€˜Cutting & Tailoringâ€™ of 25 members in each batch. We covered 2 batches with a duration of 6 months. We have conducted Entrepreneurship Development Programme covering 25 PMRY beneficiaries for 15 days which was sponsored by DIC, Jalpaiguri, WB. NABARD Regional Office, Kolkata sponsored a few programmes on â€˜SHG awarenessâ€™ which were conducted by AICURD.

detailsOfAchievement: All India Citizens Alliance for Progress & Development (AICAPD) - a Delhi based NGO - has been working towards the development of economically and socially underprivileged and backward people, especially children of field and construction labourers whose nomadic life deprives them of a consistent livelihood and permanent habitat. The children of these disadvantaged group lack basic education, live in utter poverty while their parents work as field or construction daily wage labourers. AICAPD has helped so far nearly 60 odd children grow and find their vocation, complete higher studies and a few have found good placement in reputed organizations. These children are from the neighbourhood - children of presswalas, drivers, mali, housemaids, sweepers and casual workers who find it difficult to afford normal schooling because of financial cosntraints and other pressing demands of their homes. AICAPD firmly believes that by providing systematic basic education up to class VIII and subsequently giving skill based vocational education to this section of the society can go a long way in helping them stand on their own feet and support themselves and their families. AICAPDâ€™s prime objective is to set up INNOVATION SCHOOLS which will target the children of the weaker sections of the society, initially in Delhi and NCR region, and subsequently by extending the program to other states as more volunteers join in the mission. The motto of these Innovation Schools is to provide good quality education to poor children who, for some reason or the other, have been denied admission to good schools. The children will be provided with books, stationery and other basic study materials to help develop and sustain their interest in studies. Once through class VIII, the focus will shift to giving them job oriented vocational training.

detailsOfAchievement: ALL INDIA CONFEDERATION OF THE BLIND All India Confederation of the Blind (AICB) is a body of blind persons working for and with its blind brothers and sisters. It is made up of grass-roots and State-level Associations/Organizations working with the blind. It has 25 affiliates across the country. AICB is one of the three national affiliates of the World Blind Unionâ€”the sole representative body of the blind at the world level. The Confederation has now completed over 35 years of its existence. As we look back, we derive some satisfaction from the fact that we have traversed quite a long distanceâ€”from a small rented office to its own premises housing a variety of services; from just one part-time employee to the present number of over 80 staff members; from a meager fund of just a few hundred rupees to the present budget of over 35 million rupees; from hardly any activity to over 20 projects and services. The Confederationâ€™s work has been receiving appreciation and commendation from various quarters. It has been adjudged the Best NGO in the disability sector for 2006 by the Government of India and presented the corresponding National Award by the then President of India on December 3, 2006. During the year 2009 and 2012, the Confederationâ€™s Braille printing press was adjudged the best in the country and was awarded a Citation and cash Award of Rs. One Lakh each time on the occasion of 200th birth anniversary of Louis Braille in a grand function organized by the Government of India on 4th January, 2009 and on 6th February, 2013 respectively. Its Secretary General was honoured by the President of India on 31st March, 2014 by conferring Padma Shri Award for his outstanding service to blind community. The Confederation runs the following programmes and services: â€¢ Highly progressive School for blind children in a rural setting. â€¢ Training in vocational courses like Braille stenography and advanced IT skills. â€¢ Model Community-based rehabilitation programmes of the rural blind in several States. â€¢ Eye care, eye health and blindness prevention. â€¢ Training of the lately blinded. â€¢ Production of thousands of volumes of Braille books and journals for children and adults through the largest Braille printing press in the country. â€¢ Recording of college text books and making the same available to blind students free of charge. â€¢ Free hostel for college going blind girl-students. â€¢ Merit scholarships and computers/laptops for higher education of blind girls. â€¢ Capacity development, especially for visually impaired youth and women. â€¢ Care of the visually impaired elderly persons. â€¢ Research projects for opening up new educational and employment opportunities. â€¢ Bringing out a number of new publications and Handbooks for visually impaired women, teachers etc. â€¢ Intense lobbying and advocacy including judicial interventions for the visually impaired. For more information, please visit our website www.aicb.org.in

Award instituted to acknowledge the work done by Malayali women to serve our society â€¢ IGSSS Shrestha Puruskar,2011, by the Indo Global Social Service Society in New Delhi for pioneering work in bringing significant changes in the lives of street and working children. â€¢ Nominated in 2009 for the "Right Livelihood Award" and was one of the finalists for the award. â€¢ Women of Social Work Excellence by Manava Seva Dharmasamvardhani Charitable Trust for Social Service Consciousness, Chennai, on 27 February 2002. â€¢ Childrens Development Khazana started by Butterflies in 2001 received the Second Prize in the 2006 Global Development Network Award for the Most Innovative Development Project. This award is given to the institution whose ongoing project embodies a fresh approach to an important development need and holds the greatest promise for benefiting the poor in developing and transition countries. Criteria include the degree of innovation and the potential for broad application of the project in other countries. â€¢ The Ramachandran Ikeda Award 1999 was conferred on Butterflies in appreciation of their work in education, healthcare and recreation of street and working children. Mahindra & Mahindra Finance granted financial support to buy a vehicle to use it as health van and provide support in rescue & emergencies to children through Butterflies Childline 1098 services in South Delhi, South East & Nizamuddin Raily station. It is a 24 hours telephone outreach service for children in crisis and need of emergency care & protection. This vehicle is been used in rescue activities, to take children to CWC
The project was supported by Department of Women and Child Development, Government of Delhi and All India Instutute of Medical Science to estimate the number of children in substance use in Delhi.

Support in expansion of Butterflies Resilence Centre Childline service for children in crisis. A short stay home that provides psychosocial, medical and legal support to children in crisis, the Resilience Centre is a licensed shelter home for boys registered under the Juvenile Justice (Care and Protection of Children) Act 2000, as amended in 2006. It has a capacity to accommodate 15 children at a time who stay in the resilience centre until their restoration/ repatriation with their families.

Butterflies School of culinary and Catering (BSCC) and Mobile Education. A one year vocational training programme in food preparation and catering and has proved important skills like decision making, leadership, teamwork, management, entrepreneurship, communication, etiquette and discipline. BSCC provide basic necessities for practical training, a coordinator, professional nutritionist. All trainees registered with NIOS for their academic growth.

Childrens Development Khazana (CDK). Conceptualized and initiated by Butterflies in the year 2001 CDK primary objective is to impart life skills education teach them to be responsible prioritise needs budget and save. Children between the age group of 9-18 years are the members volunteer managers and promoters of CDK. Any rural urban and ethnic communities child can be a member of Khazana which is their own and is run by children themselves under the guidance of adult facilitators.

Grant for child health and sports Cooperatives programme for creating a safe environment for street-connected and marginalized children in urban Delhi, Mumbai and Jaipur and ethnically marginalised children in rural Kerala, Odisha and Jharkhand who are at risk of migrating and losing family care. The child lead programme aims to build knowledge and life skills among children using sport as a tool to overcome social isolation, increase self-esteem and tackle safety issues.

Building a child-friendly environment at Andaman Islands, strengthening child participation and community awareness for the protection of childrens rights.Since 2005, Butterflies is closely working with children in Tsunami affected areas of Andaman

Building community capacity and participation to prevent violence against children in five communities in Delhi with high concentration of street connected children. The goal of the project is to prevent violence against children from homeless and vulnerable families by establishing sustainable child social protection systems in the communities with the participation of community people and children, and thus ensuring children are able to grow up in a safe and caring home and community.

Continuation Programme for the Rehabilitation of Street Children in Delhi. Butterflies with its unique non- institutional approach endeavours to empower street and working children in various situations in the city of Delhi. The street programme interventions are rooted in places like bus terminals, railway stations, market places, parks and so on, where the children live and work. Butterflies works in 13 contact points in Delhi and reaches out to more than 2,000 children on a daily basis.

Butterflies Resilience Center (RC) is a short stay home where Children who are rescued require temporary care and protection during the process of restoration and rehabilitation. This will be provided at RC which is being constructed for temporary care centre for children in need of care

The Health Cooperative. Child Health Co-operative (CHC) is a unique initiative started in 1995. Key objectives of CHC is to promote safe and healthy living among children and communities. The cooperative has regular workshops where the children deliberate on health, nutrition and environment issues and gain knowledge regarding prevention of diseases and the importance of nutrition and a clean environment.

Childlne 1098 is a 24x7 telephone outreach service for children in need of care and protection being implemented by the Ministry of Women and Child Development, Government of India in partnership with NGOs. Butterflies is managing the services in 2 Districts of Delhi and at Nizamuddin Railway Station. The Ministry provides resources through Childline India Foundation.

The program is being implemented through close collaboration with State Education Departments in Delhi and Uttarakhand.

Establishment and management of Child Health and Sport Cooperatives as safe, supportive and participatory spaces for children to learn life skills.
